things taking ^ place ^ or having occurred at a distance
No amount of explanation
conveys the idea unless they
learn to read - Machinery
is equally inexplicable and
money nearly as much
so untilluntil they see it in
actual use - They are familiar
with barter alone and in the centre
of the country
where gold is
totally unknown
if a button &
sovereign were
left to their
choice they
would prefer
the former
on account of
its having an
eye

The father in law ^ of Sekeletu Motibe
in beginning to learn seemed
to himself in the position
of the doctor who was obliged
to drink his potion before
the patient to shewshow it contained
nothing detrimental and after
he had mastered the alphabet
and reported the thing so far
safe, Sekeletu and his
young com-panionscompanions came
forward to try for themselves
He must have resolved
to watch the effects of the
book against his views
on polygamy and abstain
whenever he precievedperceived
any inclination/ tendency towards
ordering him / to put his
wives away - A number
of men ^ learned the alphabet in a
short time and were set to
teach others but before much
progress could be made I was
on my way to LoandoLuanda

As I had declined to
name anything as a present
from Sekeletu except a canoe
to take me up the river - he
brought ten fine elephantselephant's tusks and
laid them down beside my
waggon - He would take
no denial - though I told
him I should prefer to see
him trading with Fleming who
had come for the purpose -
I had during the
most ofeleven years of my
previous
course I invariably abstained from
taking presents of ivory from
an idea that a religious
instructor degraded himself
by accepting gifts from
those whose spiritual welfare
and not ththeir worldly wealth
he professed to seek My
precedence of all traders in
the line of discovery put
me often in the way of
very handsome offers but
I always advised the
donors to sell their ivory
to traders who would
be sure to follow and when at some
future time they had become
rich they might remember
me or my children - When
Lake Ngami was discovered
I might have refused
permission to the trader
who accompanied us but
when he applied for leave
to form part of our company
73 77
knowing that Mr OswelOswell would
no more trade than myself
and that the people of the
Lake would be disappointed
if they could not dispose
of their ivory I willingly granted a mya sanction
without which his people
would not at that time
have ventured so far - This
was clearly preferring the
interest of another to my
own

And so when we succeeded
in reaching Sebituane
Hehe expected us to trade
but we preferred sending
125 a [messenger down to the
Lake requesting two traders
who had ^
gone thither
to the Chobe to come for that purpose
^ and they did so very much
to their own advantage -

My attention had however
been directed to the subject
of "missionaries trading"
by a great deal of mumbling
and grumbling among
upstart extemporaneous traders
who flocked into the country
after the discovery of the
Lake - The disappointment
of these ^ fellows who were generally runaway butchers
bakers and cabmen was
extreme on finding the blacks
so soon awakened to a
sense of their own interests
and the value of ivory
74 78
and their and some Cape Colonial merchants who
had been silly ^ foolish enough to risk
their money in such hands
reiterated the charge givenmade to them
in excuse for the failure of
their speculations, that the
missionaries appropriated
all the commercial profits
of the natives to themselves
As I was well aware that
the missionaries at Kuruman
for instance had got formal permission
from the Colonial government
for a trader to settle on the
spot and thereby relieve
them from all liability
to business transactions
with the natives and that
that mantrader had become so rich
as to enable him after some
years to retire, and that
it was notorious thatin the
country that no missionary
whatever had become rich
I for the first time in my
life began to examine
the propriety of question of
missionaries engaging
in trade - and as the change
of opinion which took
place in consequence had
a considerable influence
in my subsequent course
I may explain that it seems
75 79
a matter beyond controversy
even that "if we sow unto
unto the heathen' spiritual things
it would be quite right "to reap
carnal things" St Paul at
least had very few doubts
on the matter - We who open
up new markets for commerce
and render the countries of
savages safe for traders to
enter might therefore with
perfect propriety avail
ourselves of our position
to benefit our families by
fair and honourable dealing
Thise propriety of this becomes
more apparent when we
remember that we might
thereby prevent the extortions
of unprincipled adventurers
and provide for those whom
in consequence of the
missionary's pay
affording a confessedly "a bare subsistence"
are by the husband and
father's death rendered entirely
dependantdependent on charity But
though the case appears so
fair when put in this
way I believe if a missionary
put the theory into practice
it would materially mar
his usefulness as a spiritual
teacher - The cares of business
would leave little leizure
andor inclination for more
serious & important matters
76 80
The conclusion I came to
therefore was, that Itit is quite lawful but not expedient
tofor missionaries to trade -
When I was fully satisfied
on this point I felt no
hesitation in departing from
my hitherto scrupulous avoidance
of even the appearance
of trading - In all the journiesjourneys
I had undertaken the extra
expenses were defrayed from
my salary of £100 per annum
This sum is sufficient to
enable a manmissionary to live comfortably
in South Africa supposing
he has a garden capable of
yielding corn & vegetables
or if he makes a journey
to the Colony every two or
three years for supplies
of articles of European articles
of consumption produce - But should he
consider ^ that his time asis sacredly
devoted to his calling and
that six or eight months
cannot be lawfully spent
in getting Colonial supplies
at a lower figureprice merely
than ^ they can be had ^ at from
itinerant traders, the sum
mentioned is sufficient for
only but the plainest ^ poorest fare and
poolainest apparel - As we
never could feel ourselves
justified in making journeys
77 81
to the Colony for the sake of making
cheaper bargains the most
frugal living was necessary
to enable us to be a little
charitable to our own people
and strangers, but when
to this wasere added extra
travelling expenses and presents
to the chiefs (always
larger than
those of any
trader who
moreover
recievereceived articles
of greater value
than they give) and ^ the wants of an increasing
family, it was difficult to
make ^ both ends meet - Presents
to the chiefs whom we
visited were always given
and nothing accepted in return
but when Sebituane ^ (in 1851) offered
me some ivory I changed
my plan, took it, and was
able by its sale to present
his son with a number of
really useful articles of a
higher value than I had ever
been able to dopresent before to any
chief - In doing this I of
course appeared to trade
but being perfectly conscious
of the right to do so if I chose
and the purity of my motives
in acting as I did I felt
perfectly easy in my mind
But as I still held the
view of the inexpediency
of combining the two professions
I was delighted by the generous
proposal of one of the most
78 82
honourable merchants of
Cape Town to risk a sum
of money in Fleming's hands
for the purpose of attempting
to developedevelop a trade with
the Makololo - It was to
this man I referred them
for trade with the tusks which
Sekeletu presented for my
acceptance - but thehe ^ the chief refused
to take them backaway - The
goods which Fleming had
brought were ill adapted
for the ^ use of the natives but he got a
pretty good load of ivory in
exchange: and though it was his
first attempt at trading and
the distance travelled over
made the expenses enormous
he was not a loser by the
trip - Other traders followed
and as they demanded 90 lbs
of ivory for a musket and
the Makololo knowing nothing
of steeylyards supposed that
they were meant to cheat
them declined to trade except
by counting one bull's tusk
& one cow selephant's tusk for
each gun - This would average
70 lbs of ivory at which sells
at the Cape for 5/ per pound
for a second hand musket
worth 10/ - I being sixty miles
79 83
distant did not witness this
trading but anxious to
enable my countrymen to
drive a brisk trade told
the Makololo to sell my
tusks for whatever they
could get - Seventy tusks
were for sale but from
want of understanding each
other's talk no trade was
established and when I passed
the spot some time afterwards
I found ^ that the whole ofremains of
that ivory - The whole had
been destroyed by an accidental
fire which broke out in
the village when all the people
were absent - Success in
trade is as much dependantdependent
on knowledge of the language
as success in travelling

I had brought as presents
an improved breed of goats
fowls and a pair of cats -
An superior bull was
bought but I could not bring
it on account of its having
becoming footsore - As they
are very fond of improving
the breed of their domestic
animals the Makololo were
80 84
were much pleased with my
selection - The ^ I endeavoured to
bring the ^ bull was in
performance of a promise
made to Sebituane before
he died - Admiring a calf
which we had with us
he proposed to give me
a cow for it which in
their ^ native estimation was offering
three times its value - I
presented it ^ to him at once and
promised to bring him a
better - Sekeletu was much
gratified by my attempt
to keep my word withgiven to his
father -

They have two breeds of
cattle among them - One called
the Batoka because
captured from that tribe is
of diminutive size but
very beautiful - Many resemble
closely the short horns of our
own country - They are very
tame and remarkably
playful - They may be seen
lying on their sides by the fires
in the evening and when
the herd goes out he the herdsman often
precedes them and has only
to commence capering to
set them all a-gambolinga-gambolling -
The meat is superior to
that of the large animal
81 85
The other or Barotse ox is
much larger and has
large horns and they comes
from the fertile Barotse
valley - andThey stand high on
their legs - oftenoften nearly 6 feet at
the withers and they have
large horns - ^ Those of Oneone of a
similar breed ^ that we brought from
the Lake measured from
tip to tip 8 ½1/2 feet

The Makololo are in the
habit of shaving off a little
from one side of the horns
of these animals when still
growing in order
to make them curve in
that direction and assume
fantastic shapes - The stranger
the curvature the more
handsome it is ^ the ox is believedconsidered to be
and the longer this ornament
of the pencattle pen is spared
to beautify the herd - This
is a very ancient custom
in Africa for the tributary
tribe of Ethiopia are seen
on some of the most ancient
monuments bringing contorted
horned cattle into Egypt -

All are remarkably fond
of their cattle and spend
much time in ornameantingornamenting
and admiring them - Some
are branded all over with
a hot knife so as to cause
a permanent discolouration
of the hair in lines like a
zebra - Pieces of skin two
or three inches long &
broad are detached and
allowed to heal in a
dependantdependent position around
the head - and if that is
beautiful it is difficult
to concieveconceive in what their
notion of beauty consists
The women at least have
somewhat the same ideas
on this point ^ of what constitutes
comeliness with ourselves
They came frequently and
asked for the looking glass
and their remarks heard, they made -
while I was ^
engaged in reading
and apparently
not attending
to them - on and on
their on
first seeing themselves
therein were amusingly
ridiculous - "Is that me?"
"What a big mouth I have?!
"My ears are as big as
pumpkin leaves" "I have
no chin at all" or "I would
have been pretty but am
spoiled by these high cheek
bones" "See how my head
shoots up in the middle"
83 87 13
laughing vociferously all the
time while at their own jokes -
They readily percieveperceive any
defect in each other
and give nicknames accord-
-ingly - One man came toalone
to have a quiet pore overgaze at his
own features once when ^ he thought I was
Stet ? asleep - After twisting his
mouth about in various
directions he remarked
to himself "people say
I am ugly" and how very
ugly I am indeed!"

The Makololo use all
the skins of their oxen for
making either mantles
or shields - ^ For Thethe former,
the hide is stretched out by means
of pegs and dried - Ten or
a dozen men then collect
round it with small adzes
which when sharpened
with an needle iron bodkin
are capable of shaving off
the substance of the skin
on the fleshy side untilluntil
it is quite thin. The operation
is performed by dragging
the adze to the performer
deledelete himself while the edge is
applied firmly to the skin
84 88
when sufficiently thin
a quantity of brain is smeared
over it and some thick
milk - Then an instrument
made of a number of
iron spikes tied to round
a piece of wood so that
the points only project
beyond it - is applied to
it in a carding fashion
untilluntil the fibres of the
bulk of it are quite
loose - Milk or butter a is
applied to it again and
it forms a garment as
soft as cloth - nearly -

The shields are made
of hides partially dried in
the sun and then beaten
with hammers untilluntil itthey
isare stiff and dry - Two
broad belts of a differently
coloured ox skin are sewed
into itthem longitudinally and
a sticks inserted to make
itthem not easily bent - They The
shield is are a great protection
in their way of fighting
with spears - but they also
trust largely to their agility
in springing aside from
the coming javelin - The
shield assists when so many
a spears are thrown that
85 89
it is impossible not to
recievereceive some one - Their
spears are light javelins
and judging from what
I have seen them do in
elephant hunting I believe
they can, when they have
room to make a run
and discharge ^ them with the assistanceaid
of the jerk of stopping,
throw them between 40
and fifty yards. They give
them an upward direction
in the discharge so that
they come down on the
animal with accelerated
force - I saw a man
who in battle recievedreceived
one in the shin - The
excitement of the moment
prevented his feeling anything
pain at the time but when
the battle was over the
blade was found s to have
split cleft the bone and become
so impacted in the cleft
that no force could extract
it - It was necessary
to take an axe and
press the split bone asunder
before the weapon could
be taken out -

86 90
About the end On the 30th of of May I was
seized with fever for the first
time. We reached the town
129 of Linyanti on the [23d and
as my habits were suddenly
changed from great activity
to comparative inactivity
at the commencement
of the cold season I suffered
from a severe attack of
stoppage of the secretions
closely resembling a common
cold - Warm baths and
drinks relieved me and I
had no idea but that I was
now relievedrecovering from the effects
of a chill, got by leaving
the warm waggon in the
evening in order to conduct
family worship at my people's
fire - But on the 2d
of June - a relapse shewedshowed
to the Makololo who knew
the complaint that my
indisposition was no other
than the fever ^ with which I have
since made a much closer
acquaintance - Cold east
winds now prevail ^ at this time and
as they come over the extensive
flats inundated by the Chobe
as well as many others
where pools of rain water
are now drying up many
they may be supposed
87 91
to be loaded with malaria
& watery vapour and many cases of fever
follow - The usual symptoms
of stopped secretion are
manifested shivering and
a feeling of coldness though
the skin is quite hot to the touch of
another - The heat in the
axilla - over the heart and
region of the stomach was in
my case 100˚ but along
the spine and at the nape
of the neck 103˚ - The internal
processes secretions were all with the
exception of the kidneys &
liver stopped - The latter
in its efforts to free the
blood of noxious principlesparticles
often secretes enormous
quantities of bile - There
waere pains along the spine
and frontal headache
Anxious to ascertain whether
they natives possessed any
the knowledge of any
remedy of which we were
ignorant I invited requested
the assistance of one of
Sekeletu's doctors - He put
some roots into a pot with
water and when it was
boiling placed it on a spot
beneath a blanket thrown
around me and it -
88 92
This did produced an immediate
effect but he got a small
bundle of different kinds
of medicinal woods and
burning them in a potsherd
nearly to ashes used the
smoke and hot vapour
arising from them as an
auxiliary to the other in
causing diaphoresis, A
mild aperient in com-
-bination with quinine is
an important aid in
curing the fever as it
seems to have the same
stimulating effects on
the alimentary canal as
these means have on the
external surface - Purgatives
or indeed any violent
remedies are injurious
and the appearance of a
herpetic eruption near the
mouth is regarded as an
evidence that no internal
organ is in danger -

89 93
The Makololo had made
a garden and planted maize
for me that as they remarked
when ^ I was parting with them
to proceed to the Cape I might
have food to eat when I
returned as well as other
people - The maize was
now pounded by the woman
into fine meal - This they
do in large wooden mortars
the exact counterparts of
which may be seen
depicted on the Egyptian
monuments - Sekeletu added
to this good supply of meal
ten or twelve jars of honey
each of which contained
about two gallons: Liberal
supplies of earth nuts - (arachis
hypogoeaarachis hypogaea) were also furnished
every time the tributary
tribes brought their dues
to Linyanti and an ox
given for slaughter asevery
often as week or two -
Sekeletu also appropriated
two cows to be milked
for us every morning
and evening - This was
in accordance with the
acknowledged rule throughout
this country that the chief
should feed all strangers
90 94
who come withon any special
business to him and take
up their abode in his kotla
A present is usually given
in return for the hospitality
but except in cases where
their aboriginal customs
have been modified bynothing
would be asked - Europeans
spoil thes feeling that
hospitality is the sacred
duty of the chiefs by what
in other circumstances is
laudable conduct - They No
sooner do they arrive that
than they offer to purchase
food and instead of waiting
till a meal is prepared
for them in the evening
cook for themselves and
then ^ often decline to partake
of that which has been
made ready for their use -
A present is also given
and before long the natives
come to consider expect
a present without having
given any equivalent

Strangers frequently
have acquaintances among
the underchiefs to whose
establishments they turn
aside, and are treated on the
same principle that others
are when they are guests
91 95
of the chief - so generally is
the duty admitted ^ that one of the
most cogent arguments
for polygamy is that a
manrespectable man with
only one wife could not
entertain strangers as he
ought - This reason has
especial weight where
the women are the chief
cultivators of the soil &
have the controulcontrol over
the corn as at Kolobeng -
The poor however who
have no friends often
suffer much hunger
and the very kind attentions
Sebituane lavished on all
such was one of the
reasons of his great pop-
-ularity in the country -

The Makololo cultivate
a large extent of country
around their villages -
Those of them who are real
BasutasBasutos still retain the
habits of that tribe and
may be seen going out
with their wives with
their hoes in hand - a
phenomenonstate of things never witnessed
at Kolobeng or in any
Bechuana or Caffre tribe
92 96
The great chief Moshesh
affords gives an example to his
people annually ofby not
only takeing the hoe in
hand but working hard
with it on certain public
occasions - His BasutasBasutos
are of the same family
with the Makololo to whom
I refer - The younger
Makololo who have been
accustomed to lord it
over the conquered Makalaka
from their infancy have un-
fortunately no desire
to imitate the agricultural
tastes of their fathers
and expect their subjects
to perform ^ all the manual
labour - They are the
aristocracy of the country
and once possessed
almost unlimited power
over their vassals - Their
privileges were however
much abridged by Sebituane
himself
